snippet: The study, still in a preliminary stage, found that lung cells exposed to e-cigarette vapor showed cancerous reactions similar to cells exposed to tobacco smoke.
abstract: Study funded by National Institutes of Health finds that nicotine-laced vapor generated by electronic cigarettes promoted development of cancer in human lung cells in same way that tobacco smoke does; initial findings of study, which is still in preliminary stages, may attract interest of federal officials who are considering how to regulate e-cigarettes.
lead_paragraph: The study, still in a preliminary stage, found that lung cells exposed to e-cigarette vapor showed cancerous reactions similar to cells exposed to tobacco smoke.

headline.main: Early Data in E-Cigarette Study May Raise Safety Concerns
headline.print_headline: E-Cigarette Study Data May Raise Concerns
